title: Unilateral Hearing Loss and Disequilibrium with Functional Overlay
chief_complaint: I feel generally unsteady, especially when walking in grocery store aisles or seeing moving objects. I also have trouble hearing in my right ear.

problem_summary.onset: 6 years prior following barotrauma from an air hose incident.
problem_summary.course: Fluctuating symptoms with a history of multiple surgeries (ossiculoplasty, fistula repairs) and inconsistent audiological findings.
problem_summary.associated_symptoms: Unsteadiness, visual motion sensitivity, history of vertigo, otalgia (past), headache with nausea/photophobia.
problem_summary.functional_impact: Chronic unsteadiness led to wheelchair use at one point; currently avoids grocery store aisles due to motion sensitivity.
problem_summary.goals_motivation: Restore ability to move in grocery store aisles without symptoms.

history.present_illness: Patient reported normal MRI at outside clinic.
history.otologic_history: History of barotrauma and multiple middle ear surgeries.
history.noise_exposure_history: Barotrauma from air hose 6 years ago.
history.prior_management: Previous exploratory surgery and fistula repairs.

tests.name: Other
tests.key_findings: CT scan of temporal bones without contrast.

numeric_results.Findings: Thinning of the roof of the superior canal on the right ear but no definite areas of focal bone dehiscence. Temporal bones otherwise unremarkable.

history.present_illness: Presented for evaluation of UHL and disequilibrium. Reports reduced hearing in right ear.
history.otologic_history: Complex history of fluctuating mixed loss. Surgeries included 'glued bones' ossiculoplasty and two perilymphatic fistula repairs.
history.prior_management: Hearing aid obtained for right ear but not used.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Left ear normal. Right ear showed severe conductive hearing loss inconsistent with other findings. Air-bone gaps 65-75 dB HL. Positive Stenger results.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.key_findings: Excellent word recognition at low sensation level, inconsistent with severe loss.

tests.name: Acoustic reflexes
tests.key_findings: Normal reflexes bilaterally, which contradicts the severe conductive loss presented in pure tones.

numeric_results.Tympanometry: Normal pressure and compliance bilaterally (Type A)

numeric_results.Interpretation: Normal outer hair cell function bilaterally

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Obtained after counseling regarding inconsistencies. Results indicate essentially normal hearing with slight low-frequency conductive component.

tests.name: Other
tests.key_findings: Comprehensive vestibular battery (VNG, Rotary Chair, Posturography, VEMPs).

numeric_results.VEMPs: Normal Left, Absent Right (likely secondary to middle ear surgeries)

history.present_illness: Follow-up for otologic, psychiatric, and physical therapy evaluation.

tests.name: Other
tests.key_findings: Scarring on TM, tympanosclerosis. TM slightly thickened but mobile. No spontaneous nystagmus. No active fistula.

tests.name: Other
tests.key_findings: Mini International Neuropsychiatric Interview (MINI). No significant depression or anxiety. Possible vestibular migraine noted.

tests.name: Other
tests.key_findings: Umbrella optokinetics testing induced a 'warm' feeling similar to grocery store symptoms. VOR and gait normal.

overall_audiologic_summary: The patient initially presented with results suggesting severe conductive hearing loss in the right ear; however, objective measures (OAEs, ABR, Acoustic Reflexes) indicated normal auditory function. Following counseling on these inconsistencies, behavioral thresholds improved to normal levels (0-15 dB HL) with excellent speech recognition, confirming a diagnosis of pseudohypoacusis (functional hearing loss) overlaying a very mild conductive component. Vestibular testing was normal except for absent right VEMPs, likely due to prior surgeries.
counseling_points: Your physiological tests (OAEs and ABR) show that your inner ear and hearing nerve are working normally, despite the difficulty you felt during the first hearing test.
The second hearing test confirmed that your hearing sensitivity is actually within the normal range.
Your dizziness appears to be related to visual motion sensitivity (feeling unsteady in grocery aisles) rather than an active ear problem like a fistula.
We recommend physical therapy exercises to help your brain get used to these visual motions again.
notes_for_actor: Portray a patient who is anxious about their hearing and balance but not malingering for financial gain; the functional loss may be a conditioned response or psychological manifestation.
During the initial hearing test, be inconsistent and show difficulty, but during the 're-test' after the audiologist explains the objective results, cooperate fully and respond to soft sounds.
Describe the dizziness as being triggered by visual patterns (grocery aisles) rather than spinning vertigo.
